There are a lot of creative ideas in this thread that merit looking 
into. =
 Ultimately empirical comparisons would be the most revealing 
when it come=
s to alternative methods, and a lot of you present 
clever hypotheses.

How=
ever, I can't help feeling that something more simple is going 
wrong in th=
e situation Bas describes.  That is, I'm not sure the 
problem is really to=
 do with my original simple speciation scheme.  
It sounds more like there =
is a system parameter problem.  I'm really 
wondering why the compatibility=
 threshold has to go above 40 before 
species are getting barely inclusive.=
  It sounds like the whole 
population is spread out (in terms of either to=
pologies or weights, 
or both) like crazy.  Why would that happen in only 1=
00 generations?
Bas, what is the rate at which you add nodes and links?  Al=
so, what 
is the strength of your mutations?  Finally, what are the 
coeffi=
cients of the compatibility distance equation?  (they could be 
too big)

I=
t would be instructive to observe several examples of genomes that 
are out=
side of 40 distance from each other.  What is causing that 
huge distance? =
 It's possible that structure has been added willy-
nilly and speciation wo=
uld thus have no way of handling the 
explosion.

In my experience, I have =
never seen a speciation dynamic so out of 
control as the one Bas describes=
 unless some other parameter is 
screwy.  Therefore, while I think all the =
creativity in this thread 
is fantastic, I think it really isn't addressing=
 the core problem 
Bas is having.  I could be wrong, of course.  But it's w=
orth trying 
to debug the situation a little before turning to alternative =

methods.  (With the rationale that alternative methods would be no 
more l=
ikely to solve an unrelated systemic problem than the original 
method.)

P=
lease don't take this as discouraging the exploration of 
alternative speci=
ation schemes.  I have to say that this thread is 
one of those enlightenin=
g and substantive tradings of ideas that one 
rarely encounters on most int=
ernet newsgroups.  I'm just saying 
Bas's specific problem might be somethi=
ng else.

ken
